Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Techniques for High Dimensional Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The onset of "big data" has led to an increased appreciation of the value of large data sets in both industrial and academic settings. Typically, the analysis of such data sets begins by modeling the data as a high dimensional system, and so an understanding of the behavior of such systems (and techniques for dealing with them) has become equally important. This award supports a mathematical investigation of the behavior of such systems using techniques introduced by the researcher in previous work with collaborators. These techniques have led to the resolution of a number of open problems across various mathematical fields, including the Kadison-Singer problem and the existence of Ramanujan graphs of all sizes and degrees. This project aims to further develop substantial connections with research across numerous fields of science, including convex optimization, real algebraic geometry, functional analysis, combinatorics, and probability. The award also supports plans to focus interdisciplinary activities of particular benefit to students associated with the project.

On a technical level, the project focuses on two areas of research: (A) to develop a theory of ''finite free probability,'' a collection of ideas lying in the intersection of random matrix theory, convex optimization, real algebraic geometry, and polynomial geometry, and (B) to generalize the previously mentioned techniques so as to widen their potential application. This includes extending the ideas to bivariate polynomials as well as a non-Hermitian setting. In the direction of (B), the project aims to address some of the obstacles that hinder the application of the current techniques (for example, the need for real rootedness of associated polynomials) by investigating analogous behaviors in more general settings. This would be a necessary part of extending (A) to non-Hermitian settings, for example, as such objects no longer satisfy the conditions necessary to apply the current techniques. Extensions in this direction would also open the possibility of application to new areas such as quantitative geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is with great pleasure that I am able to characterize the outcome of this project as successful, both in terms of achieving the goals listed in the original proposal, but also in ways beyond what had been anticipated.  The original goal was to provide the foundational framework for a collection of ideas known as "finite free probabilty." For much of this project, the researchers depended on ideas from more established fields of mathematics to suggest the most fruitful directions and most promising approaches.  This project, however, has seen the tools of finite free probability mature to an extent that they are starting to "give back" to these other areas of mathematics.

A number of phenomena have now been discovered in the context of finite free probability which point to undiscovered results in other areas of mathematics.  The most natural setting for such phenomena occurs in the realm of random matrix theory.  A new inequality in finite free probability, for example, suggests a possible generalization of an important structural theorem concerning the spectra of random matrices (the so-called "single ring theorem") in unexpected ways.  Similarly, work in finite free processes has suggested a new type of matrix Brownian motion that would represent a vast leap in terms of the complexity of systems that are currently accessible by random matrix theory methods.  Applications of this have already appeared in the field of finance and it would not be surprising to see applications in statistical physics soon follow. 

An equally interesting (but more theoretical) outgrowth of this project has been a new approach to an important convolution in (infinite) free probability that has eluded researchers for decades.  Much of the theory of (infinite) free probability has developed in two parallel tracks (combinatorial and analytic) and this dual nature has been the source of numerous discoveries in the field.  One particular tool, the "box product" convolution, has been studied for decades on the combinatorial side of the field, but an analytic representation has eluded researchers.  In an exciting breakthrough, an analytical representation of the box product was discovered in finite free probability, and we believe this will open the path to the development of some long-sought tools in (infinite) free probability.

In a more unexpected development, some of the tools that were discovered under this project have found valuable applications in engineering.  One way to measure the stability of a chemical structure or fabricated material is to analyze the so-called "spectral gaps" in an associated operator.  Maximizing these spectral gaps leads to chemicals and materials with optimal physical properties.  The theory developed in this project provides new ways to understand spectral gaps and new methods for constructing operators with maximal spectral gaps, which could lead to the development of chemicals and materials with new and improved properties.

This project has, in many ways, provided exciting new directions for mathematicians and engineers to explore.  While the original focus was on directions that would help to build the foundational framework of the new field of finite free probability, there have already been a number of unexpected applications to established areas of mathematics.  This will undoubtedly be the legacy of this project and an achievement that was likely still decades away without its support.
